After raising $5.1 million last quarter, $2.2 million more has come in already in October, I'd say they're on track for $10 million this quarter at least, will probably blow past most if not all of the supposed "top tier", which have been trending downwards for some time now.
 
 Meanwhile in the New Hampshire primary... probably going to be the 1st.
 
 http://nh2008.blogspot.com/2007/10/ron-paul-beats-thompson-huckabee-in-new.html
 
 polling 7.4%, its by no means a lead, but I'm starting to think just maybe they can pull it off. The media advertisements should kick in, and no doubt there will be thousands of self organised volunteers descending on the state in the weeks leading up. It isn't just 7.4%, it's 7.4% up from 3% a month ago, and 1% 2 months ago.
 
 It truly amazes me that a candidate that has been given the shaft in the debates and by the traditional media is doing so well.

I guess they didn't think that the Internet would have such an influence, but thankfully it did. The one thing I'm concerned about is that the campaign won't have enough time to get Ron some real name recognition. The primaries have been moved to such early dates that the clock is really ticking for Dr. Paul. And considering the dirty tricks that have been pulled by the establishment, like secretly moving up the date when one can register as a Republican and vote in the primaries, it's going to be a struggle for Dr. No. Voting on the same electronic voting machines that gave GW the presidency twice is also a big problem. But let's just hope that miracles still happen. BTW I just received my bumpersticker in the mail. It's the same one that Dr. Paul has on his desk in DC: http://unalienablerights.us/gallery/albums/2008prez/ronpaulsdesk.jpg I also absolutely love this Ron Paul pic, it basically sums up everything that Ron Paul is about: http://www.rense.com/1.imagesH/paulheart_dees.jpg

 He is not just for pulling out of the UN, he is for pulling out of the UN and shifting to a "mind our own business" foreign policy. I have no problem with this at all. The problem I DO have is with the folks who want to pull us out of the UN so we can feel free to intervene anywhere we want, any time we want, and for any reason we want.
 
 He is not just for overturning Roe v Wade, he is for overturning Roe V Wade and all federal laws related to abortion and putting the issue where it belongs...in the hands of the states. 
 
 IMO, if they can come up with the $10 million they are looking for, the media will have to start treating him like a contender. Also IMO I think that if he can win New Hampshire, he has a shot at the white house. A win in NH would ensure that everybody hears his name and has a chance to take a look at him, as well as removing the "throw your vote away" stigma from him.
 
 Typically straw polls are better at picking winners in primaries than general polls are, and RP has WON every straw poll in NH by a wide margin.

 I'm always suspicious of telephone surveys since I don't know how the people that were polled were selected and also since I don't know how the questions were asked. You can ask a person two things that basically mean the same thing but are formulated differently and you will get 2 different answers.
 Straw polls are IMO a far better way of measuring a candidates chances because those polls are attended by people who will put in some effort to vote and as such are much closer to the target audience. And since straw polls are about directly picking a candidate, there can be no shenanigans by wording questions differently.
Symbiote

obvious_child

Well it's not like the US abides by any of these treaties, so from a practical point of view, nothing will change.

 
 We abided to several of the START and SALT treaties with the Soviets. And we're abidding to the bio-weapons convention (even through the Russians didn't). Just recently the US and Russia issued a joint statement for their middle and short range missile bilateral convention to become global. I'm not happy with the US-India nuclear pact that is essentially ignoring the NPT, but pulling out of that is a bad, bad idea. As for the conventions on caliber, I realize the US does break that, but only clandestinely. 
 
 
The US continues to make new nukes

 
 Replacement for the most part. And the Russians do this as well.
 
 
new biological weapons

 
 When? Last I recall, the US was on the extended time-line for complete destruction. Double entry bookkeeping would suggest that we are not making new ones.
 
 
doesn't care about making and selling landmines, clusterbombs and depleted uranium projectiles.

 
 Then it's a good thing we never signed those treaties eh? 
 
 The treaties we have signed (aside from Bush's fake one with Putin) have been largely abided to. 
 
 
So pulling out of these treaties will result in absolutely no change whatsoever, it'll just be business as usual.

 
 I don't agree with that at all, the ones you hit us for are ones we haven't signed. So we can't pull out of such a treaty.

I'm always suspicious of telephone surveys since I don't know how the people that were polled were selected and also since I don't know how the questions were asked. You can ask a person two things that basically mean the same thing but are formulated differently and you will get 2 different answers.
 Straw polls are IMO a far better way of measuring a candidates chances because those polls are attended by people who will put in some effort to vote and as such are much closer to the target audience. And since straw polls are about directly picking a candidate, there can be no shenanigans by wording questions differently.

 
 Considering Rasmussen Reports has been the most accurate polling agency over the last 8 years, I'd say they provide the best measurement. IIRC the straw polls predicted Howard Dean in 2004....way off.

I am aware of it. Its why I don't support him. He is also no ally for gay rights.

 Actually, he's more gay friendly than all the others, but he doesn't see these things as being about gay rights or black rights or any other rights. He only sees the rights that each and everyone of us has as an individual.
 So when it comes to for example marriage, he sees it as a voluntary contract between two people regardless of their sexual orientation and the government should stay out of it. In other words, he's not anti or pro gay marriage. He just thinks that it's not his nor the governments business to either legalize or prohibit any kind of marriage.

Huckabee raised taxes during his time in the statehouse in AK. He also was supportive of illegal immigrants and college tuition. Get the facts.

 
 You're doing the generalities thing in politics where politicians avoid specifics and talk in sweeping phrases like "oh, he raised taxes." Well, you need to research WHAT taxes. What he lowered as opposed to what he raised, and why. And what was the economic situation of the state was at the time. You need to keep in mind that state economics and national economics are very different. You're the one who is short on facts here.
